Date of the arrest and subsequent legal developments, including the threat charge against Hakeem Jeffries and the ongoing hearing on potential release pending trial.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from January 2021 to 2025 covers the timeline of the Capitol riot, Moynihan's conviction, presidential pardon, and the subsequent threat charge, illustrating a sustained public concern about political violence.

keyTakeAways: Christopher Moynihan, a New York man convicted of Capitol riot-related charges, was arrested for threatening to kill Democratic House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries.
Moynihan previously received a presidential pardon from Donald Trump along with other January 6 defendants, sparking criticism from Jeffries over the blanket nature of the pardon.
Moynihan made threatening statements via text, stating he would 'kill Jeffries for the future' and that he 'cannot allow this terrorist to live', indicating a clear intent to commit violence.
The arrest occurred after law enforcement received an anonymous tip about Moynihan's recent increase in homicidal ideations and drug abuse, suggesting possible mental health and substance use issues.
Although Moynihan did not engage in violent acts during the Capitol riot, his actions — such as taking photos from a senator’s desk — were seen as disruptive and politically charged.
A New York judge ordered Moynihan to remain in prison while awaiting a hearing on whether he can be released pending trial on a terroristic threat charge.
The case reflects broader concerns about political threats and violence, especially following high-profile assassinations such as that of Charlie Kirk.
Moynihan’s prior history includes opiate addiction and misdemeanor convictions, which attorneys cited in seeking treatment and a reduced sentence during sentencing.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A man convicted of participating in the January 6 Capitol attack, Christopher Moynihan, was arrested on a charge of threatening to kill U.S. House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries. Despite being pardoned by President Donald Trump earlier in 2025, Moynihan made threatening text messages stating he would 'kill Jeffries for the future' and that he must be eliminated. The threat emerged amid heightened concerns over political violence following the assassination of right-wing commentator Charlie Kirk. Moynihan, who had a history of opiate addiction and prior misdemeanors, is currently serving time for Capitol-related offenses and remains in prison pending a hearing on a terroristic threat charge. The case underscores ongoing tensions between political accountability, presidential pardons, and the dangers of extremist rhetoric targeting public officials.
title: Pardoned Capitol rioter arrested on charge that he threatened to kill Hakeem Jeffries
